coredata.dc:title: Quantum chemical explanation of the “hyper” spectrum of the carbon monoxide complex of cytochrome P-450
coredata.dc:creator: Jung, Christiane
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
π INDO CI calculations for the carbon monoxide complex of cytochrome P-450 show that the “hyper” spectrum is produced by strong interaction between the UV and the Soret bands. This interaction depends on the sulfur ligand charge and on the iron-sulfur distance. The “hyper” spectrum can only be explained assuming a partial negative sulfur charge less than “−0.6”.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 113, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 8 February 1985 QUANTUM CHEMICAL EXPLANATION OF THE "HYPER" SPECTRUM OF THE CARBON MONOXIDE COMPLEX OF CYTOCHROME P-4SO Chnstiane JUNG Central Institute of Molecular Biology of the Academy of Sciences of the ODR, Department of Hemecatalysis. 1115 Berlin, German Democratic Republic Received 8 September 1983; in final form 7 September 1984 TT INDO CI calculations for the carbon monoxide complex of cytochrome P-450 show that the "hyper" spectrum is produced by strong interaction between the UV and the Soret bands. This interaction depends on the sulfur ligand charge and on the iron sulfur distance. The "hyper" spectrum can only be explained assuming a partial negative sulfur charge less than "-0-6"- 1. Introduction Cytochrome P-450 (P-450) is the terminal oxidase of a monooxygenase system which catalyzes the in- sertion of an oxygen atom of molecular oxygen into the carbon hydrogen bond of aromatic and aliphatic compounds. In comparison to other hemoproteins P-450 shows some peculiarities in spectral properties [1]. One of these peculiarities is shown in the optical spectrum. For most hemoproteins in the ferrous low- spin state the Soret (or B) band and the UV band ap- pear at about 420 and 340 350 nm, respectively. The ratio of the oscillator strengths UV: Soret is 0.3 0.5 : 1. This spectral behaviour is called a "normal" spec- trum- In contrast, the carbon monoxide complex of P-450 (P-450 CO) shows strongly red-shifted Soret (450 nm) and UV (370 nm) bands with a ratio of the oscillator strengths of 1 1. This unusual spectral property is called a "hyper" spectrum [2]. From comparative studies of P-450 and of so-called "model complexes" using different spectroscopic methods like optical, MCD, resonance Raman and EPR spectroscopy [ 1 ] it was concluded that the fifth heme iron ligand should be the deprotonated sulfur atom of a cysteine which induces the spectral peculiarities. Champion et aL [3] could prove an iron sulfur bond by reso- nance Raman studies on isotopically enriched (^Fe, ^S) and natural abundance ("Fe, ^S) samples of 0 009-2614/85/S 03.30 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) P-450 from bacteria Pscudomonas putida- There are two explanations of the "hyper" spec- trum of P-450 CO using quantum-chemical methods- From IEHT calculations Hanson et aL [2] postulate a new transition (S' (sulfur) -> e* (porphyrin)), not seen in the carbon monoxide complex of hemoglobin (Hb CO), which should produce the UV band and should interact with the Soret band resulting in this red-shift- From all-valence INDO CI calculations Loew and Rohmer [4] conclude that the Sorei band of Hb CO originates from four intense transitions (mixture ofa^y, a.^ -> e*, &.-^-_yt -* e* and d7r - --d^ ) which split in P-450 CO producing the UV and red-shifted Soret bands. Both theories neglect or underestimate that the "normal" spectrum already ex- hibits the UV band [5] which might be important for understanding the "hyper" spectrum of P-450 CO. To follow this idea we calculated the electronic transi- tions of ferrous low-spin porphyrin complexes with different axial ligands [5] using a modified INDO CI method in ir-approximation adapted for transition- metal complexes with organic ligands [6]. This paper presents the detailed results of a com- parative analysis of the electronic transitions of the bisimidazole complex (mod el for cytochrome b5). for the imidazole carbon monoxide complex (model for Hb CO) and for the sulfur carbon monoxide complex (model for P-450-CO)- 589 Volume 113. number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 8 February 1985 2. Theoretical method For interpretation of the absorption spectra of porphyrin ferrous complexes we extended the INDO CI method on the calculation of electronic transitions of transition-metal complexes with organic ligands - [6]. Table 1 summarizes the o- and ir-parameters for the axial ligands and the iron- The parameters for the porphyrin ligand are given in ref. [14]. The Slater ex- ponents for calculation of the overlap integrals are taken from ref. [15] for the carbon, nitrogen and oxygen atoms and from ref. [16] for the sulfur atom. A value of 1.65 is found to be best for the porphyrin complexes [ 18] Fig. 1. shows the structural model for the porphyrin complexes. The porphyrin ring lies in the x,y plane. The plane of the imidazole ligand is set into the plane spread by the z-axis and the connecting line between the porphyrin center and the meso carbon atoms ac- cording to the X-ray data for myoglobin [19]. For cytochrome b^ the planes of both imidazole ligands are assumed to be perpendicular to each other to main- tain the fourfold symmetry. A linear structure for the Fe C 0 arrangement is used for the carbon monoxide complexes as it results from X-ray data of "picket- fence" porphyrin complexes [20]. The values 1.136, 1.8 and 2.0 A are used for the C 0, the Fe CO and the Fe imidazole distance, respectively [15,21,22]. The iron sulfur distance in cytochrome P-450 is varied between 1 8 and 2.6 A- The geometry for the porphyrin ligand is taken from ref. [15]- The electron- ic transitions are calculated by interaction of 74 singly excited configurations ofE symmetry- Table 2 Calculated and experimental electronic transitions of reduced cytochrome b5 Band a) Calculation b) Experimentc) chaise-transfer character (%) and main configurations (%) Qy 2.6 (P- Fe),0.4(P-* D 18-07 (009) i/(0-0) 18-0 (0-25) Ox 2-6 (P- Fe);0-4(P-* I) 18.0B (0-09) r(O-l) 19-1 98 (am, a2u -1-c^ By 1 4(Fe- <-P);0.4(I-* P) 25-46 (2-18) 23.7 (2.26) BX 1 4(Fe- + P), 0-4(1-)- P) 25-48 (2-17) 98(a,u, a2u c^) UV^ 49-9 (Fe -*-P);142(I --P) 2g.77 (0-59) 29-0 (0-76) Wy 49.9(Fe P); 142(1 ^P) 28-79 (0 60) ai(cg0rax)-b?u) x, y 46(eg(Iiii) biu)+ 40(a2u.b2u eJ) 43(a2u, bau eJ)-*- 28 (eg(lni) - bTu) 43(a2u,b2u-"eg)+ 27(eg(m)-*bTu) 35-30 (003) 36-71 (0-003) 36-73 (0-003) a) x andy indicate the polarization. t>) r in 103 cin"1, /= oscillator strength, P = porphyrin Tr-system, Fe = iion-dTr orbitals, I = imidazole ;r-system, definition of the charge-transfer character in ref [6], molecular orbitals are given in fig. 2. c) Reduced cytochiome bs,/is determined by Gaussian fitting analysis. 591 Volume 113, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 8 February 1985 3. Results 3.1. Complexes of the "normal" spectral type Tables 2 and 3 show the calculated and experimental electronic transitions for reduced cytochrome be and for Hb CO- All important electronic transitions (Q, B, LTV) are twofold degenerate and polarized in the porphyrin plane which matches experimental polariza- tion studies. [24]. The Q and B transitions are IT IT* transitions of the porphyrin ligand (97 98%) an~d are caused by the molecular orbital transitions a iu, a^u -i" S (fig- 2). a^y and a^y are pure porphyrin molecular orbit- als. The amount of the axial w-system (iron plus axial ligands) in the porphyrin molecular orbital e* is less than 2%. Molecular-orbital schemes for cytochrome b^. Hb CO and cytochrome P-450- originates from the molecular orbital transition ^("ax) -> ^u- ^lu is a P"" porphyrin molecular or- bital. SfX^ax) is localized in the axial Tr-system to 55 57%. The UV transition possesses charge-transfer con- tributions of 64% and 57 70% for cytochrome fag and Hb CO, respectively- The charge transfer is direct- ed from the axial w-system to the porphyrin. The N and L transitions which result from the porphyrin transitions a'^, b^e^ (43 93%) appear above 3 5600 cm 1- Considenng that the B transition (Soret band) is systematically obtained 1800 cm"1 at too high ener- gies, the calculations correctly reflect the experimen- tally observed characteristics of the "normal" spectrum: (i) position of the Soret band (B transition) at 420 nm (23.8 X 103 cm-1) and the UV transition at about 340 nm (29.4 X 103 cm-1); (ii) ratio of the oscillator strengths UV . Soret of about 0.1 0.3 : 1. 3-2. "Hyper" spectral type ofP-450-CO Fig. 3 shows the calculated energies and oscillator strengths of the Q, B and UV bands in dependence on the iron sulfur distance. The results are demon- strated for four different assumed sulfur charges (0, 0-3, 0.6 and 1). For a fixed sulfur charge the UV transition synchronously shifts to lower energies, decreasing the iron sulfur distance. In a certain range of the iron sulfur distance, the UV transition and the D transition change their places in the energy order- i - 7B "tiBi^t ^0 22 r Of 0 Fig- 3. Calculated energies (E) and calculated oscillator strengths (/I of the electronic transitions Q, B (Soret) and UV for P- 450 CO in dependence on the iron sulfur distance (r. A) demonstrated for different assumed sulfur charges (65)- 593 Volume 113, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 8 February 1985 Because of the same symmetry of the B and the UV transitions (E according to C^y) there is no distance for which the B and the UV transitions exhibit the same energy ("non-crossing rule" for potential sur- faces of same symmetry [25]). Regarding the oscilla- tor strengths firsi. the bathochromic shift of the UV transition is connected with an increase of its oscilla- tor strength and with a decrease of the oscillator strength of the B transition. After going beyond the crossover range, the oscillator strength of UV decreases and that ofB increases again. There is a certain iron sulfur distance ("anomaly" distance) for which the calculations reveal a ratio of the oscillator strengths of 1:1- For this distance the B and the UV transitions are red-shifted in comparison to the respective transi- tions of Hb CO *. These are the very spectral charac- teristics of the "hyper" spectrum It is shown in r';f * For Hb CO the energies and oscillator strengths of" the transitions Q, B and UV ore independent of the iron unida- zole distance [18,23] [5] that there is a dependence of the "anomaly" dis- tance on the sulfur charge. Only for negative charges less than " 0.65" is the "hyper" spectrum obtained by the calculations. Table 4 represents a detailed char- acterization of the electronic transitions using the sul- fur charge " 0.5" and the iron sulfur distance "2-175 A". The results for the other pairs of sulfur charge and iron sulfur distance are the same [18] In all cases the Q transition is to 97% a TT TT* transition of the porphynn (a^u, 3311 -> eg). The B and the UV transitions show a strong mixture (table 4) [5] reflect- ing the increase of the charge-transfer contribution to the B transition of 24 26%. The charge-transfer char- acter of the UVband ranges between 55 and 59%. a^y, a^u and b^y are pure molecular orbitals of the porphynn ligand. e* and CgOr^) are localized in the axial ff-system to 3% and 80%, respectively. The Q, B and UV transitions zie twofold degener- ate, which is in accordance with polarization measure- ments ofP-450 CO crystals [2]. Discussion The present -n INDO CI study leads to a qualitatively different explanation of the "hyper" spectrum ofP- 450 CO than that given by Hanson et al. [2] and by Locw and Rohmer [4]. Concerning the origin of the electronic transitions, the calculations reveal two main results: (i) The Q, the B (Soret) and the UV bands in P- 450 CO are produced by the same type of molecular- orbital transitions as in other ferrous low-spin porphy- rin complexes (reduced cytochrome b5, Hb CO and Hb O^ [5]). The main configurations are a]u, a2u -> e^ and eg(TT^) -* b^ #. Two effects of the sulfur ligand in P-450 CO can be distinguished- On the one hand, the negative charge at the fifth ligand, which shows in a low ionization potential for the ligand TT-OI- bital, induces an increased iron Tr-back-donation to the porphyrin. The resulting increase of the negative -n- charge of the porphyrin correlates with the red-shift of the Soret band [5]. On the other hand, the large overlap integral <sulfur3p?T|iron 3d7T>, which has about three times the value of (imidazole nitrogen 2p7r liron 3d7r>, causes a decrease of the energy dif- ference between the molecular orbitals ep(irg^) and b^u- This effect favours the interaction between ep(?r^) -* b^u and a^u, a2u ->"e^ and causes an intensity bor- rowing of the UV band from the Soret band. It is concluded that the possibility to produce a "hyper" spectrum should be in relation to the presence of axial ligands with 3p valence orbitals like sulfur (or phos- phorus). Experimental studies on "model complexes" using different axial Ugands [28] seem to support this conclusion. (ii) The formation of the "hyper" spectrum de- pends on the sulfur charge and the iron sulfur dis- tance- For a sulfur charge of " l" the UV transitions (eg(ir^) - b^y) is already so strongly red-shifted that it does not interact with a^y. a2u "*'e^- Using an iron sulfur distance of 2 1 2.3 A found for "model" complexes" and P-450^^2 by X-ray measurements +:f: First calculations of the electronic transitions ot'P-450 CO using a simple PPP-like method, which does not in- clude the (i-polarization, revealed the charge-transfer transi- tion Cg(Trax) -f" b^u between the Q and the B transitions. The qualitatively similar charge-transfer transition eg(ir;ix) ~* a2u was indicated to produce the UV band [27]- [29] and by EXAFS studies [30], respectively, a sul- fur charge between 0.3 and 0.6 is proposed for F- 450 CO- Such partial negative charge at the sulfur ligand may be induced by hydrogen bonding to amino acid residue of the protein [18]- A possible hydrogen bonding is also discussed by Traylor et al. [31]. The assumption of hydrogen bonding to explain the par- tial negative charge of the sulfur ligand seems not to be valid for the "model complexes" which also show the "hyper" spectrum [32]- Counter ions may reduce the effective negative charge of the sulfur ligand in "model complexes". In summary, the comparative analysis of the absorp- tion spectra ofP-450 CO and further ferrous low- spin porphyrin complexes like Hb CO, Hb 0^, cy- tochrome bj and P-450-02 [5] using the n INDO CI method leads to a reasonable explanation of the "hy- per" spectrum ofP-450 CO. Further theoretical studies are necessary to check if this explanation is al- so valid for the "hyper" spectrum ofdimercaptide ferric low-spin porphyrin complexes [28] which can be regarded as "isoelectronic" with P-450 CO con- cerning the formal net charge of the whole complex- References [1] H- Rein, C- Jung, 0. Dolphin, J Am- Chem- Soc- 98 (1976)1607. 596 ) ~* a2u was indicated to produce the UV band [27]- [29] and by EXAFS studies [30], respectively, a sul- fur charge between 0.3 and 0.6 is proposed for F- 450 CO- Such partial negative charge at the sulfur ligand may be induced by hydrogen bonding to amino acid residue of the protein [18]- A possible hydrogen bonding is also discussed by Traylor et al. [31]. The assumption of hydrogen bonding to explain the par- tial negative charge of the sulfur ligand seems not to be valid for the "model complexes" which also show the "hyper" spectrum [32]- Counter ions may reduce the effective negative charge of the sulfur ligand in "model complexes". In summary, the comparative analysis of the absorp- tion spectra ofP-450 CO and further ferrous low- spin porphyrin complexes like Hb CO, Hb 0^, cy- tochrome bj and P-450-02 [5] using the n INDO CI method leads to a reasonable explanation of the "hy- per" spectrum ofP-450 CO. Further theoretical studies are necessary to check if this explanation is al- so valid for the "hyper" spectrum ofdimercaptide ferric low-spin porphyrin complexes [28] which can be regarded as "isoelectronic" with P-450 CO con- cerning the formal net charge of the whole complex- References [1] H- Rein, C- Jung, 0. head.ce:title: Quantum chemical explanation of the “hyper” spectrum of the carbon monoxide complex of cytochrome P-450

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Central Institute of Molecular Biology of the Academy of Sciences of the GDR, Department of Hemecatalysis, 1115 Berlin, German Democratic Republic

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: π INDO CI calculations for the carbon monoxide complex of cytochrome P-450 show that the “hyper” spectrum is produced by strong interaction between the UV and the Soret bands. This interaction depends on the sulfur ligand charge and on the iron-sulfur distance. The “hyper” spectrum can only be explained assuming a partial negative sulfur charge less than “−0.6”.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Structural and functional relationships, biochemical and physico-chemical aspects of mixed function oxidases
Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol.
